info.title: Hummingbot API
info.description: API for managing Hummingbot trading instances

get.description:
Check if the Docker daemon is running and accessible.

Pings the Docker daemon to verify connectivity. This is useful for health checks
and to verify Docker is available before attempting container operations.

Use this endpoint before performing Docker operations to ensure the daemon is
responsive, or as part of a system health check routine.

List locally available Docker images, optionally filtered by name.

Retrieves all Docker images that have been pulled to the local system. Can be filtered
to show only images matching a specific name pattern (e.g., "hummingbot" to show only
Hummingbot images).

Use this endpoint to discover what images are available for creating new bot containers,
or to verify that a specific image version has been pulled.

List all currently running Docker containers.

Retrieves information about all Docker containers in the "running" state. Can be
filtered by container name to show only specific containers (e.g., all Hummingbot
bot containers).

Use this endpoint to monitor running bots, check container health, or get container
IDs for management operations.

List all stopped (exited) Docker containers.

Retrieves information about all Docker containers in the "exited" state. These are
containers that have been stopped or have completed execution. Can be filtered by
container name.

Use this endpoint to find stopped bots that may need to be restarted, cleaned up,
or have their logs inspected.

post.description:
Remove all exited (stopped) Docker containers.

Performs a bulk cleanup of all containers in the "exited" state. This frees up
disk space and cleans up the container list. This operation is irreversible -
container logs and state will be permanently deleted.

Warning: This removes ALL exited containers, not just Hummingbot containers.
For selective removal, use the remove-container endpoint instead.

Use this endpoint for periodic cleanup of old containers to free disk space
and reduce clutter in container listings.

Remove a Hummingbot container and archive its trading data.

Stops and removes the specified Hummingbot container, then archives the bot's
instance data (configurations, logs, database) either locally or to S3. This
ensures trading history is preserved before container removal.

Important: This endpoint ONLY works with Hummingbot containers (names must start
with "hummingbot-"). For general container removal, use Docker CLI directly.

Use this endpoint when decommissioning a bot to ensure its data is safely
archived before cleanup.

Stop a running Docker container.

Sends a stop signal to the specified container, allowing it to gracefully shut down.
The container will move to the "exited" state but will not be removed. Use this
to pause trading activity without losing container state.

Use this endpoint to temporarily stop a bot (e.g., during maintenance) while
preserving the ability to restart it quickly.

Start a stopped Docker container.

Restarts a previously stopped container. The container will resume with its
existing configuration and state. This is faster than creating a new container
as no initialization is required.

Use this endpoint to resume a bot that was previously stopped, or to restart
a bot that exited unexpectedly.

Start downloading a Docker image in the background.

Initiates an asynchronous pull operation for the specified Docker image. The pull
runs in the background, allowing the API to remain responsive. Use the /pull-status
endpoint to monitor progress.

Use this endpoint to download new Hummingbot versions or other required images
before creating containers.

get.description:
Get the status of all Docker image pull operations.

Returns the current status of all image pulls that have been initiated, including
completed, in-progress, and failed operations. Use this to monitor download progress
after calling /pull-image.

Use this endpoint to track image download progress and verify completion before
creating containers with newly pulled images.

Get Gateway container status.

Retrieves the current running status and configuration of the Gateway Docker container.
Use this endpoint to verify Gateway is online before making DEX trading requests.

post.description:
Start Gateway container.

Starts the Gateway Docker container with the specified configuration. Gateway provides
connectivity to decentralized exchanges (DEXs) like Jupiter, Uniswap, Meteora, and Raydium.

Stop Gateway container.

Gracefully stops the running Gateway Docker container. Any pending transactions
should be completed before stopping. Wallet keys remain encrypted and persistent.

Restart Gateway container.

Restarts the Gateway Docker container. Required after configuration changes (e.g., updating
RPC URLs, adding tokens, modifying connector settings) for changes to take effect.

get.description:
Get Gateway container logs.

Retrieves recent log output from the Gateway Docker container. Useful for debugging
connection issues, transaction failures, or monitoring Gateway activity.

parameters.name: tail

schema.description: Number of log lines to retrieve (1-10000)
schema.title: Tail

parameters.description: Number of log lines to retrieve (1-10000)

get.description:
List all available DEX connectors.

Returns all configured DEX connectors with their supported trading types, chains, and networks.
Use this to discover which DEXs are available for swaps and liquidity operations.

Supported Connectors:
    - jupiter: Solana swap aggregator (Router)
    - uniswap: Ethereum/L2 AMM and CLMM
    - meteora: Solana CLMM (DLMM)
    - raydium: Solana AMM and CLMM

schema.title: Response List Connectors Gateway Connectors Get

get.description:
Get configuration for a specific DEX connector.

Retrieves the current configuration settings for a DEX connector including
slippage settings, gas limits, and other connector-specific parameters.

schema.title: Response Get Connector Config Gateway Connectors  Connector Name  Get

post.description:
Update configuration for a DEX connector.

Modifies connector settings such as slippage tolerance, gas limits, and other
connector-specific parameters. Gateway restart is required for changes to take effect.

schema.title: Response Update Connector Config Gateway Connectors  Connector Name  Post

get.description:
List all available blockchain chains and their networks.

Returns all blockchains supported by Gateway with their available networks.
Use this to discover which chains are configured for DEX trading.

Supported Chains:
    - solana: Solana blockchain (networks: mainnet-beta, devnet)
    - ethereum: Ethereum mainnet and testnets
    - polygon: Polygon PoS (networks: mainnet, mumbai)
    - arbitrum: Arbitrum L2 (networks: mainnet, goerli)

schema.title: Response List Chains Gateway Chains Get

get.description:
List all liquidity pools for a connector and network.

Returns all configured liquidity pools for the specified DEX connector and network.
Pools are pre-registered in Gateway's configuration and can be used for CLMM operations.

Removes a registered pool from Gateway. This prevents the pool from being used
for future CLMM operations. Does not affect any existing on-chain positions.

get.description:
List all available networks across all chains.

Returns a flattened list of all configured networks in the format 'chain-network'.
This is the primary interface for discovering available networks for DEX operations.

schema.title: Response List Networks Gateway Networks Get

get.description:
Get configuration for a specific network.

Retrieves the current configuration for a network including RPC endpoints,
gas settings, and other chain-specific parameters.

schema.title: Response Get Network Config Gateway Networks  Network Id  Get

post.description:
Update configuration for a specific network.

Modifies network settings such as RPC endpoints, gas configuration, and other
chain-specific parameters. Gateway restart is required for changes to take effect.

schema.title: Response Update Network Config Gateway Networks  Network Id  Post

get.description:
Get available tokens for a network.

Returns all tokens registered in Gateway for the specified network. Tokens can be
filtered by symbol or name. Use this to discover available tokens for swaps.

parameters.name: search

schema.description: Filter tokens by symbol or name (case-insensitive)
schema.title: Search

schema.title: Response Get Network Tokens Gateway Networks  Network Id  Tokens Get

post.description:
Add a custom token to Gateway's token list.

Registers a new token in Gateway's configuration for the specified network.
This enables the token to be used in swap operations. Gateway restart required
for changes to take effect.

schema.title: Response Add Network Token Gateway Networks  Network Id  Tokens Post

delete.description:
Delete a custom token from Gateway's token list.

Removes a token from Gateway's configuration for the specified network.
Does not affect any existing positions or balances. Gateway restart required
for changes to take effect.

schema.title: Response Delete Network Token Gateway Networks  Network Id  Tokens  Token Address  Delete

post.description:
Create a new wallet in Gateway.

Generates a new wallet keypair for the specified blockchain and stores it encrypted
in Gateway. The wallet can be used for DEX trading operations (swaps, liquidity).

schema.title: Response Create Wallet Gateway Wallets Create Post

post.description:
Show private key for a wallet.

Decrypts and returns the private key for a wallet stored in Gateway.
Use this to export wallets or for manual signing operations.

WARNING: This endpoint exposes sensitive information. Handle the response
securely and never log or expose the private key.

schema.title: Response Show Private Key Gateway Wallets Show Private Key Post

post.description:
Send a native token transaction.

Transfers native tokens (SOL, ETH, etc.) from a Gateway wallet to another address.
Use this for simple transfers of the chain's native currency.

schema.title: Response Send Transaction Gateway Wallets Send Post

get.description:
List all account names in the system.

Retrieves a list of all trading accounts that have been created in the system.
Each account can have multiple exchange connectors (API credentials) associated with it.
Use this endpoint to discover available accounts before querying their credentials or balances.

The 'master_account' is always present and is the default account created during system setup.
Additional accounts can be created to organize trading across different strategies or portfolios.

List all configured exchange connectors for an account.

Retrieves the names of all exchange connectors that have API credentials configured
for the specified account. Each connector represents a connection to a centralized
exchange (CEX) like Binance, Kraken, or OKX.

Use this endpoint to see which exchanges an account can trade on before placing orders
or checking balances.

schema.title: Response List Account Credentials Accounts  Account Name  Credentials Get

post.description:
Create a new trading account.

Creates a new account with default configuration files copied from the master_account.
The new account will have its own isolated directory for storing exchange credentials
and configuration settings.

Use this endpoint to organize trading across different strategies, risk profiles,
or to separate paper trading from live trading credentials.

After creating an account, use POST /accounts/add-credential/{account_name}/{connector_name}
to add exchange API credentials to the new account.

parameters.name: account_name

schema.description: Name for the new account. Must be unique and not already exist.
schema.title: Account Name

parameters.description: Name for the new account. Must be unique and not already exist.

post.description:
Delete an account and all its associated credentials.

Permanently removes an account and all of its stored exchange credentials.
This operation:
1. Stops all active connectors for the account
2. Removes the account from the in-memory state
3. Deletes the account's credentials directory and all files within it

WARNING: This action is irreversible. All API credentials stored for this account
will be permanently deleted. Ensure you have backups of any credentials you may need.

The 'master_account' cannot be deleted as it is required for system operation.

parameters.name: account_name

schema.description: Name of the account to delete. Cannot be 'master_account'.
schema.title: Account Name

parameters.description: Name of the account to delete. Cannot be 'master_account'.

post.description:
Delete exchange credentials for a specific connector.

Removes the API credentials for a specific exchange connector from an account.
This operation:
1. Stops the connector if it's currently running
2. Removes the connector from the in-memory account state
3. Deletes the encrypted credentials file from disk
4. Clears the connector from the internal cache

Use this endpoint to revoke access to an exchange or when rotating API keys
(delete old credentials, then add new ones).

Add or update exchange API credentials for a connector.

Stores encrypted API credentials for a specific exchange connector and validates
them by initializing a connection to the exchange. This operation:
1. Encrypts and saves the credentials to a YAML file
2. Initializes the connector to validate the credentials work
3. Sets up price tracking for tokens in the account's portfolio
4. Updates the account state with current balances

If credential validation fails (e.g., invalid API key), the credentials are
automatically deleted and an error is returned.

The required credential fields vary by connector. Use GET /connectors/{connector_name}/config
to see the required fields for a specific connector.

Common credential patterns:
- Binance: binance_api_key, binance_api_secret
- Kraken: kraken_api_key, kraken_secret_key
- OKX: okx_api_key, okx_secret_key, okx_passphrase

schema.description: Exchange API credentials. Required fields vary by connector.
schema.title: Credentials

get.description:
List all blockchain wallets managed by Gateway.

Retrieves all wallets that have been added to the Gateway service for DEX trading.
Gateway manages its own encrypted wallet storage, separate from CEX exchange credentials.

Each wallet entry includes:
- The blockchain chain (e.g., 'solana', 'ethereum')
- All wallet addresses registered for that chain

These wallets are used for:
- DEX trading via swap aggregators (Jupiter, Uniswap)
- CLMM liquidity provision (Raydium, Meteora, Orca)
- On-chain token transfers

Wallets are associated with the 'master_account' for balance tracking purposes.

post.description:
Add a blockchain wallet to Gateway for DEX trading.

Imports an existing wallet by providing its private key. Gateway encrypts the
private key and stores it securely. The wallet is automatically set as the
default wallet for its chain.

SECURITY WARNING: The private key is transmitted to the Gateway service over
your local network. Ensure Gateway is running locally or over a secure connection.

Supported chains:
- solana: For Jupiter swaps, Raydium/Meteora/Orca CLMM
- ethereum: For Uniswap swaps and liquidity provision
- Additional EVM chains as configured in Gateway

After adding a wallet, its balances will be automatically tracked in the
'master_account' under the key '{chain}-{network}' (e.g., 'solana-mainnet-beta').

delete.description:
Remove a blockchain wallet from Gateway.

Deletes a wallet from Gateway's encrypted storage. This operation:
1. Removes the encrypted private key from Gateway's storage
2. Clears the wallet's balance data from the account state

WARNING: This action is irreversible. Ensure you have backed up the wallet's
private key before removing it, as it cannot be recovered from Gateway.

After removal, the wallet can no longer be used for DEX trading through this
system. Any pending transactions should be completed before removing the wallet.

get.description:
List all available exchange connectors.

Returns a list of all connector names that are supported by the Hummingbot system.
These connectors can be used to connect to centralized exchanges (CEX) for trading.
Each connector corresponds to a specific exchange or trading platform.

Use this endpoint to:
- Discover which exchanges are supported
- Validate connector names before configuration
- Display available options in UI dropdowns

Common connectors include:
- Spot: binance, bybit, kucoin, gate_io, okx, htx, kraken
- Perpetual: binance_perpetual, bybit_perpetual, gate_io_perpetual, okx_perpetual

Get the configuration schema for a specific connector.

Returns the list of configuration fields required to set up a connector,
including field names, data types, and whether each field is required.
Use this to understand what credentials and settings are needed before
adding a new exchange connection.

Most connectors require API key and secret at minimum. Some exchanges
require additional fields like passphrase (Kucoin, OKX) or account type.

schema.title: Response Get Connector Config Map Connectors  Connector Name  Config Map Get

get.description:
Get trading rules and limits for a connector's trading pairs.

Returns the trading rules (minimum order size, price increments, etc.) for all
or specific trading pairs on a connector. This information is essential for
order validation before placing trades.

This endpoint uses public market data and does not require authentication.
Rules are fetched directly from the exchange.

Trading rules typically include:
- Minimum/maximum order sizes
- Price and quantity precision (decimal places)
- Minimum notional value
- Order type support

parameters.name: trading_pairs

schema.description: Filter by specific trading pairs
schema.title: Trading Pairs

parameters.description: Filter by specific trading pairs

get.description:
Get the order types supported by a specific connector.

Returns a list of order types that can be used when placing trades on this connector.
Different exchanges support different order types, so check this endpoint before
attempting to place orders with specific order types.

This endpoint uses public market data and does not require authentication.

Common order types:
- LIMIT: Order at a specific price, executes when market reaches that price
- MARKET: Order executed immediately at current market price
- LIMIT_MAKER: Limit order that will be rejected if it would immediately match (maker-only)

post.description:
Get the current state of all or filtered accounts portfolio.

Retrieves real-time portfolio balances across all configured accounts and connectors.
By default, returns cached state for fast responses. Use the `refresh` parameter to
fetch live balances from exchanges (slower but more accurate).

Use this endpoint to:
- View current holdings across all accounts and exchanges
- Monitor portfolio value in real-time
- Filter by specific accounts or connectors for focused analysis
- Get CEX-only balances quickly by skipping Gateway wallet lookups

schema.title: Response Get Portfolio State Portfolio State Post

post.description:
Get historical portfolio snapshots with pagination and configurable time intervals.

Retrieves historical portfolio state data stored in the database. Portfolio snapshots
are collected every 5 minutes and stored for analysis. Use this endpoint to track
portfolio performance over time, analyze PnL, or generate reports.

The interval parameter controls data granularity for performance optimization:
- 5m: Raw data (default, collected every 5 minutes)
- 15m: One data point every 15 minutes
- 30m: One data point every 30 minutes
- 1h: One data point every hour
- 4h: One data point every 4 hours
- 12h: One data point every 12 hours
- 1d: One data point every day

Using larger intervals significantly reduces response size and improves query performance.
For long time ranges (weeks/months), use 4h or 1d intervals.

Get portfolio distribution by token with percentage breakdowns.

Analyzes the portfolio and groups holdings by token symbol across all accounts
and connectors. Each token shows its total value, percentage of portfolio,
and detailed breakdown by account and connector.

Use this endpoint to:
- Understand asset allocation across your portfolio
- Identify token concentration risks
- View where each token is held (which accounts/exchanges)
- Generate portfolio composition reports

Get portfolio distribution grouped by account with percentage breakdowns.

Analyzes the portfolio from an account-centric view, showing the total value
and percentage of portfolio held in each account. Includes breakdown by
connector within each account.

Use this endpoint to:
- Compare holdings across different accounts
- Monitor account-level allocation
- Identify which exchanges hold the most capital
- Generate account allocation reports

Place a buy or sell order on a centralized exchange.

Submit a new order to buy or sell an asset through a configured account and connector.
Supports spot trading (BUY/SELL) and perpetual futures trading with position actions (OPEN/CLOSE).
For market orders, the price is fetched automatically from the market data feed.
For limit orders, a price must be specified.

The order is submitted asynchronously to the exchange. The returned order_id can be used
to track the order status via the /orders/active or /orders/search endpoints, or to
cancel the order via the cancel endpoint.

Cancel an active order by its client order ID.

Request cancellation of an existing open order on the exchange. The cancellation is
submitted asynchronously - a successful response indicates the cancellation request
was sent, not that the order has been cancelled. The order may still be filled if
a matching trade occurs before the cancellation is processed.

Use the /orders/active endpoint to verify the order has been cancelled, or listen
for order status updates via the MQTT message broker.

Get current open positions from perpetual futures connectors.

Fetches real-time position data directly from perpetual connectors (e.g., binance_perpetual).
Returns detailed information about each open position including entry price, current PnL,
leverage, liquidation price, and margin information.

Only perpetual connectors (those with "_perpetual" in the name) are queried. Spot connectors
are automatically excluded as they don't have positions.

The response uses cursor-based pagination for efficient traversal of large position lists.

Get currently active (in-flight) orders from exchange connectors.

Fetches real-time order data directly from the connectors' in-flight order tracking.
This shows orders that are currently open, pending, or partially filled on the exchanges.
Unlike /orders/search which queries historical data, this endpoint provides live order state.

Active orders include those in states: PENDING_CREATE, OPEN, PARTIALLY_FILLED, PENDING_CANCEL.
Orders that are fully filled, cancelled, or failed will not appear here (use /orders/search instead).

The response uses cursor-based pagination. Orders are sorted by client_order_id for consistency.

Search historical orders from the order registry database.

Queries the persistent order database to retrieve historical order records. Unlike /orders/active
which shows live in-flight orders, this endpoint retrieves completed, cancelled, and failed orders
from the database. Useful for order history analysis, trade reconciliation, and reporting.

Orders are returned sorted by timestamp (most recent first). The response supports cursor-based
pagination and time-range filtering for efficient querying of large order histories.

Get trade execution history (fills) from the database.

Retrieves historical trade fills - the actual executions that occurred when orders were
matched on exchanges. Each trade represents a fill event, which may be a partial or
complete fill of an order. Multiple trades can be associated with a single order.

Trades are returned sorted by timestamp (most recent first). Supports time-range filtering
and cursor-based pagination for efficient querying of large trade histories.

Use this endpoint for:
- Trade history reporting and analysis
- PnL calculations
- Fee tracking
- Reconciliation with exchange records

Set the position mode for a perpetual futures connector.

Configure whether the connector operates in HEDGE mode (separate long/short positions)
or ONEWAY mode (net position only). This setting affects how positions are managed:

- **HEDGE mode**: Allows simultaneous long and short positions on the same trading pair.
  Each direction is tracked separately. Useful for hedging strategies.

- **ONEWAY mode**: Only one position direction at a time per trading pair.
  Opening a position in the opposite direction closes the existing position first.

Important: Position mode can typically only be changed when there are no open positions
on the connector. Some exchanges may have additional restrictions.

get.description:
Get the current position mode for a perpetual futures connector.

Retrieves the current position mode setting (HEDGE or ONEWAY) for the specified
perpetual connector. This is useful for:

- Verifying the current mode before placing trades
- Checking mode after attempting to change it
- Building UI displays showing account configuration

post.description:
Set the leverage multiplier for a trading pair on a perpetual connector.

Configure the leverage used for margin trading on a specific trading pair. Higher leverage
amplifies both gains and losses, and increases liquidation risk. The leverage setting
applies to new positions opened on the specified trading pair.

Leverage requirements:
- Must be a positive integer between 1 and the exchange's maximum (typically 125)
- Different trading pairs may have different maximum leverage limits
- Changing leverage may fail if it would cause existing positions to exceed margin requirements

Note: This endpoint is only available for perpetual futures connectors. Spot connectors
do not support leverage.

Get funding payment history from perpetual futures connectors.

Retrieves historical funding payment records for perpetual futures positions. Funding payments
are periodic payments exchanged between long and short position holders to keep the perpetual
contract price aligned with the spot price.

Funding payments occur at fixed intervals (typically every 8 hours) and can be positive
(you receive payment) or negative (you pay). The payment amount depends on:
- Your position size
- The funding rate at the payment time
- Your position direction (long or short)

Only perpetual connectors (those with "_perpetual" in the name) are queried. Supports
time-range filtering and cursor-based pagination for large histories.

Get a price quote for a token swap.

Fetches a real-time price quote from the specified DEX aggregator without executing
a transaction. Use this to preview swap outcomes before executing.

Supported Connectors:
    - jupiter: Solana's leading swap aggregator (routes across multiple DEXs)
    - 0x: Ethereum/L2 swap aggregator

Execute a token swap transaction.

Executes a swap on the specified DEX aggregator. The transaction is signed and
submitted to the blockchain. Swap details are recorded in the database for tracking.

Supported Connectors:
    - jupiter: Solana's leading swap aggregator
    - 0x: Ethereum/L2 swap aggregator

get.description:
Get status of a specific swap by transaction hash.

Retrieves the recorded details and current status of a swap transaction.
Use this to check if a swap has been confirmed on-chain.

post.description:
Search swap history with filters.

Queries the swap history database with optional filters for network, connector,
wallet, trading pair, status, and time range. Results are paginated.

get.description:
Get swap summary statistics.

Calculates aggregate statistics for swaps matching the specified filters.
Useful for dashboards and analytics.

Get detailed information about a CLMM pool.

Retrieves comprehensive pool data including current price, liquidity distribution,
fee structure, and bin information (for DLMM pools like Meteora).

Supported Connectors:
    - meteora: Solana DLMM pools (returns bin data)
    - raydium: Solana CLMM pools (via Raydium API)
    - uniswap: Ethereum/L2 V3 pools

Get list of available CLMM pools.

Retrieves a paginated list of CLMM pools from the connector's API with comprehensive
metrics including volume, TVL, APR, and fee data. Use this to discover pools for
opening liquidity positions.

Supported Connectors:
    - meteora: Solana DLMM pools (full pool listing with metrics)

schema.description: Page number (0-indexed)
schema.title: Page

parameters.description: Page number (0-indexed)

schema.description: Results per page (max 100)

schema.description: Include pools with unverified/unknown tokens
schema.title: Include Unknown

parameters.description: Include pools with unverified/unknown tokens

post.description:
Open a new CLMM liquidity position.

Creates a new concentrated liquidity position in the specified pool with the given
price range and initial liquidity. The position is tracked in the database for
monitoring and management.

Supported Connectors:
    - meteora: Solana DLMM (Dynamic Liquidity Market Maker)
    - raydium: Solana CLMM
    - uniswap: Ethereum/L2 Uniswap V3

Close a CLMM position completely.

Removes all liquidity from the position, collects any pending fees, and closes
the position NFT. This is a permanent action - the position cannot be reopened.

Supported Connectors:
    - meteora: Solana DLMM
    - raydium: Solana CLMM
    - uniswap: Ethereum/L2 Uniswap V3

Collect accumulated fees from a CLMM position.

Withdraws all pending trading fees earned by the position without removing liquidity.
The position remains open and continues earning fees.

Supported Connectors:
    - meteora: Solana DLMM
    - raydium: Solana CLMM
    - uniswap: Ethereum/L2 Uniswap V3

Get all CLMM positions owned by a wallet for a specific pool.

Queries the blockchain directly via Gateway to get all positions owned by a wallet
in the specified pool. Returns real-time position data including current liquidity
and pending fees.

Supported Connectors:
    - meteora: Solana DLMM
    - raydium: Solana CLMM
    - uniswap: Ethereum/L2 Uniswap V3

schema.title: Response Get Clmm Positions Owned Gateway Clmm Positions Owned Post

get.description:
Get event history for a CLMM position.

Retrieves all recorded events for a position including opens, closes, fee collections,
and liquidity changes. Events are stored when operations are executed via this API.

post.description:
Search CLMM positions in the database.

Queries database-tracked positions with optional filters. Optionally refreshes
position data from Gateway before returning results. This provides historical
tracking and persistence for positions created via this API.

parameters.name: position_addresses

schema.description: Filter by specific position addresses
schema.title: Position Addresses

parameters.description: Filter by specific position addresses

get.description:
Get the status of all active bots.

Retrieves real-time status information for all bots currently being managed by the
orchestrator. This includes bots that are running, starting, or stopping. Use this
endpoint to get a comprehensive overview of your bot fleet.

The status data includes performance metrics, trading state, and health information
for each bot that has been discovered via MQTT and is actively communicating with
the orchestrator.

Get MQTT connection status and discovered bots.

Returns comprehensive information about the MQTT message broker connection used
for bot communication. This includes connection health, broker details, and lists
of bots that have been discovered through MQTT heartbeats versus bots that are
actively being managed.

Use this endpoint to:
- Diagnose connectivity issues between the API and bot instances
- Verify that deployed bots are properly communicating via MQTT
- Check broker configuration and connection state

The difference between discovered_bots and active_bots:
- discovered_bots: Bots that have sent MQTT heartbeat messages (may include orphaned bots)
- active_bots: Bots that are actively being managed by this orchestrator instance

Get the status of a specific bot.

Retrieves detailed real-time status information for a single bot instance.
This includes the bot's current trading state, performance metrics, active
orders, and health indicators.

Use this endpoint when you need detailed information about a specific bot
rather than an overview of all bots. The response includes more detailed
performance data than the bulk status endpoint.

Get trading history for a bot with optional parameters.

Retrieves the complete trading history for a specified bot, including all
executed trades, order fills, and performance data. The history is fetched
from the bot instance via MQTT and can be filtered by time period.

This endpoint is useful for:
- Analyzing trading performance over specific time periods
- Generating reports on bot activity
- Debugging trading behavior by reviewing historical trades

Note: This operation may take several seconds for bots with extensive history.
The timeout parameter can be adjusted for bots with large datasets.

post.description:
Start a bot with the specified configuration.

Sends a start command to an existing bot instance via MQTT. The bot must have
already been deployed (using deploy-v2-script or deploy-v2-controllers) and be
in a stopped state. This endpoint initiates the trading script execution within
the bot container.

Use this endpoint to:
- Resume a stopped bot with the same or different configuration
- Start a deployed bot for the first time after deployment
- Change the running script or configuration of a stopped bot

The start command is sent asynchronously via MQTT. The response indicates whether
the command was successfully sent, not whether the bot has fully started.

Stop a bot with the specified configuration.

Sends a stop command to a running bot instance via MQTT. This gracefully stops
the trading script, optionally cancels open orders, and updates the bot run
record in the database with final performance status.

Important: This endpoint only stops the trading script within the container.
The Docker container continues running and can be restarted with start-bot.
To completely remove a bot and archive its data, use stop-and-archive-bot instead.

The endpoint captures the bot's final performance status before stopping, which
is then persisted to the database for historical tracking.

get.description:
Get bot runs with optional filtering.

Retrieves historical bot run records from the database with flexible filtering
options. Each bot run represents a deployment lifecycle from creation through
stopping and archival. Use this endpoint to analyze historical bot activity,
track performance across runs, and audit bot operations.

Bot runs are created when deploying a bot (deploy-v2-script or deploy-v2-controllers)
and updated when the bot is stopped or archived. The records persist even after
the bot container is removed.

Get a specific bot run by ID.

Retrieves complete details for a single bot run record by its unique database ID.
Use this endpoint when you have a specific run ID (e.g., from a previous query
or from logs) and need the full details including deployment configuration and
final performance status.

Get statistics about bot runs.

Returns aggregated statistics across all bot run records. Use this endpoint
to get a high-level overview of bot operations including counts by status,
total runs, and deployment success rates.

This is useful for monitoring dashboards and operational reporting.

post.description:
Gracefully stop a bot and archive its data in the background.

This is the recommended way to fully decommission a bot. Unlike the stop-bot
endpoint which only stops the trading script, this endpoint performs a complete
shutdown and cleanup:

1. Captures final performance status before stopping
2. Stops the bot trading process via MQTT command
3. Waits 15 seconds for graceful shutdown
4. Monitors and stops the Docker container
5. Archives all bot data (logs, databases, configs) locally or to S3
6. Removes the Docker container
7. Updates the bot run record to ARCHIVED status

The operation runs in the background and returns immediately. The entire process
typically takes 20-30 seconds to complete.

Use this endpoint when:
- Permanently removing a bot that is no longer needed
- Freeing up server resources after a bot completes its task
- Archiving bot data for compliance or analysis purposes

Deploy a new Hummingbot instance with a V2 script.

Creates a new Docker container running Hummingbot configured with a specified
script and optional script configuration. The container is automatically started
and begins executing the trading strategy.

This is the primary method for deploying custom scripts. For controller-based
strategies, use deploy-v2-controllers instead.

The deployment process:
1. Creates a new Docker container from the specified Hummingbot image
2. Mounts necessary volumes (configs, credentials, scripts)
3. Sets up MQTT communication for bot control
4. Creates a bot run record in the database for tracking
5. Starts the container with the specified script (if auto-start enabled)

Deploy a V2 strategy with controllers.

This is the recommended method for deploying multi-controller trading strategies.
The endpoint automatically:
1. Generates a unique timestamped instance name to prevent conflicts
2. Creates the script configuration file combining all specified controllers
3. Deploys a new Docker container with the v2_with_controllers.py script
4. Creates a bot run record for tracking

Controllers are pre-configured strategy components that can be combined to create
sophisticated trading strategies. Examples include:
- DMan Maker: Directional market making with inventory management
- Grid Strategy: Grid-based trading for ranging markets
- XEMM: Cross-exchange market making

The generated instance name follows the format: {instance_name}-{YYYYMMDD-HHMMSS}
to ensure uniqueness across deployments.

get.description:
List all available V2 strategy controllers organized by type.

Retrieves all controller Python files from the controllers directory, organized by their
type (directional_trading, market_making, generic). Controllers are the core strategy
components in Hummingbot V2 that define trading logic and can be composed together.

Use this endpoint to discover available controllers before creating configurations
or to verify that a custom controller has been properly deployed.

List all saved controller configurations with their metadata.

Retrieves all YAML configuration files from the conf/controllers directory. Each configuration
defines parameters for a specific controller that can be used when launching trading bots.
Configurations are reusable and can be assigned to multiple bot instances.

Use this endpoint to browse available configurations, verify configuration deployment,
or to list configurations before editing or deleting them.

schema.title: Response List Controller Configs Controllers Configs Get

get.description:
Get a specific controller configuration by its name.

Retrieves the full configuration content from a YAML file in the conf/controllers directory.
The configuration contains all parameters needed to instantiate and run a controller,
including trading pair, connector, amounts, and strategy-specific settings.

Use this endpoint to inspect configuration details before launching a bot or to
retrieve current settings before making modifications.

schema.title: Response Get Controller Config Controllers Configs  Config Name  Get

post.description:
Create a new controller configuration or update an existing one.

Saves the provided configuration dictionary as a YAML file in the conf/controllers directory.
If a configuration with the same name exists, it will be overwritten. The configuration
should include all required fields for the target controller type.

Use this endpoint to create new strategy configurations, update existing ones,
or import configurations from external sources.

delete.description:
Delete a controller configuration file.

Permanently removes the specified configuration YAML file from the conf/controllers directory.
This action cannot be undone. The configuration will no longer be available for use
with new bot instances.

Note: Deleting a configuration does not affect bots that are already running with
a copy of this configuration. Running bots maintain their own configuration state.

get.description:
Get the Python source code of a specific controller.

Retrieves the full source code content of a controller file from the controllers directory.
Controllers are Python classes that implement trading logic and extend the base controller
classes provided by Hummingbot V2.

Use this endpoint to inspect controller implementations, review strategy logic,
or retrieve code for modification before re-uploading.

schema.title: Response Get Controller Controllers  Controller Type   Controller Name  Get

post.description:
Create a new controller or update an existing one.

Saves the provided Python source code as a controller file in the appropriate type directory.
If a controller with the same name exists, it will be overwritten. The controller code
should be a valid Python module that implements the appropriate controller base class.

Use this endpoint to deploy custom controllers, update existing strategy implementations,
or import controllers from external sources.

Note: After uploading a new controller, you may need to restart the API server for
the controller to be properly loaded into the Python runtime.

delete.description:
Delete a controller Python file.

Permanently removes the specified controller file from the controllers directory.
This action cannot be undone. Any configurations referencing this controller
will become invalid.

Warning: Ensure no running bots are using this controller before deletion.
Configurations that reference a deleted controller will fail to load.

get.description:
Get the configuration template for a controller with field metadata.

Dynamically loads the controller's Python module and extracts its configuration class
(typically a Pydantic model). Returns all configuration fields with their default values,
types, and whether they are required.

Use this endpoint to discover what configuration parameters a controller accepts
before creating a new configuration. This is especially useful for dynamically
building configuration forms in UI applications.

post.description:
Validate a configuration dictionary against a controller's configuration schema.

Dynamically loads the controller's configuration class and attempts to instantiate
it with the provided configuration values. This validates all field types, required
fields, and any custom validators defined in the configuration model.

Use this endpoint to pre-validate configurations before saving them, ensuring
they will work correctly when used to launch a bot.

get.description:
Get all controller configurations deployed to a specific bot instance.

Retrieves all YAML configuration files from the bot's local conf/controllers directory.
Each bot instance maintains its own copy of controller configurations, which may differ
from the global configurations in conf/controllers.

Use this endpoint to inspect what controllers a specific bot is configured to run,
or to audit configuration differences between bot instances.

schema.title: Response Get Bot Controller Configs Controllers Bots  Bot Name  Configs Get

post.description:
Update a controller configuration for a specific bot instance.

Merges the provided configuration values with the existing configuration for the
specified controller on the bot. Only the fields provided in the request body
are updated; existing fields not included in the request are preserved.

Use this endpoint to modify controller parameters on a running bot, such as
adjusting position sizes, spread parameters, or other trading settings.

Note: Changes take effect based on the bot's configuration reload behavior.
Some changes may require the controller to be restarted to take effect.

get.description:
List all available V1 strategy scripts.

Retrieves all Python script files from the scripts directory. Scripts are the V1
strategy format in Hummingbot that run as standalone strategy implementations.
Unlike V2 controllers, scripts contain both the strategy logic and configuration
in a single file.

Use this endpoint to discover available scripts before creating configurations
or to verify that a custom script has been properly deployed.

List all saved script configurations with their metadata.

Retrieves all YAML configuration files from the conf/scripts directory. Each configuration
defines parameters for a V1 script including the script file to use, controller configurations,
candle data requirements, and market connections.

Use this endpoint to browse available configurations, verify configuration deployment,
or list configurations before editing or deleting them.

schema.title: Response List Script Configs Scripts Configs Get

get.description:
Get a specific script configuration by its name.

Retrieves the full configuration content from a YAML file in the conf/scripts directory.
The configuration contains all parameters needed to run a script, including the script
file name, controller references, candle data settings, and market connections.

Use this endpoint to inspect configuration details before launching a bot or to
retrieve current settings before making modifications.

schema.title: Response Get Script Config Scripts Configs  Config Name  Get

post.description:
Create a new script configuration or update an existing one.

Saves the provided configuration dictionary as a YAML file in the conf/scripts directory.
If a configuration with the same name exists, it will be overwritten. The configuration
should include the script file name and any required parameters.

Use this endpoint to create new strategy configurations, update existing ones,
or import configurations from external sources.

delete.description:
Delete a script configuration file.

Permanently removes the specified configuration YAML file from the conf/scripts directory.
This action cannot be undone. The configuration will no longer be available for use
with new bot instances.

Note: Deleting a configuration does not affect bots that are already running with
a copy of this configuration. Running bots maintain their own configuration state.

get.description:
Get the Python source code of a specific script.

Retrieves the full source code content of a script file from the scripts directory.
Scripts are V1 strategy implementations that contain both trading logic and can be
run directly by Hummingbot.

Use this endpoint to inspect script implementations, review strategy logic,
or retrieve code for modification before re-uploading.

schema.title: Response Get Script Scripts  Script Name  Get

post.description:
Create a new script or update an existing one.

Saves the provided Python source code as a script file in the scripts directory.
If a script with the same name exists, it will be overwritten. The script code
should be a valid Python module that implements the ScriptStrategyBase class.

Use this endpoint to deploy custom scripts, update existing strategy implementations,
or import scripts from external sources.

Note: After uploading a new script, you may need to restart the API server for
the script to be properly loaded into the Python runtime.

delete.description:
Delete a script Python file.

Permanently removes the specified script file from the scripts directory.
This action cannot be undone. Any configurations referencing this script
will become invalid.

Warning: Ensure no running bots are using this script before deletion.
Configurations that reference a deleted script will fail to load.

get.description:
Get the configuration template for a script with default values.

Dynamically loads the script's Python module and extracts its configuration class
(if defined). Returns all configuration fields with their default values. This is
useful for discovering what parameters a script accepts.

Use this endpoint to discover what configuration parameters a script accepts
before creating a new configuration. This is especially useful for dynamically
building configuration forms in UI applications.

schema.title: Response Get Script Config Template Scripts  Script Name  Config Template Get

post.description:
Get real-time OHLCV candles data for a specific trading pair.

Retrieves candlestick (OHLCV) data from a live market data feed. The feed is created
on first request and maintained for subsequent requests, providing near real-time
data with automatic updates from the exchange.

The endpoint manages feed lifecycle automatically:
- First request: Creates and starts a new WebSocket feed to the exchange
- Subsequent requests: Reuses the existing feed for immediate data access
- Inactive feeds are automatically cleaned up after the configured timeout period

Get historical OHLCV candles data for a specific time range.

Fetches historical candlestick data from the exchange for backtesting, analysis,
or charting purposes. Unlike the /candles endpoint, this retrieves data for a
specific historical time range rather than maintaining a live feed.

The data is fetched directly from the exchange's historical data API, so availability
depends on the exchange's data retention policies. Most exchanges provide several
years of historical data for major trading pairs.

get.description:
Get information about all currently active market data feeds.

Returns status information about all candle feeds currently maintained in memory.
Use this endpoint to monitor resource usage, debug connectivity issues, or understand
which market data streams are active.

Each active feed represents a WebSocket connection to an exchange that consumes
server resources. Feeds are automatically cleaned up after a period of inactivity
(configurable via feed_timeout setting).

Get current market data service configuration settings.

Returns the current configuration values that control how market data feeds
are managed, including cleanup intervals and timeout periods. Useful for
debugging and understanding the server's market data management behavior.

These settings affect all market data feeds and determine:
- How often the system checks for and removes inactive feeds
- How long a feed can remain idle before being cleaned up

Get list of all exchange connectors that support candle (OHLCV) data feeds.

Returns the names of all connectors that have implemented candle data fetching.
Use this to discover which exchanges can be used with the /candles and
/historical-candles endpoints.

Not all exchange connectors support candle data. This endpoint helps you
determine which connectors are available for candlestick chart data and
technical analysis.

post.description:
Get current mid prices for one or more trading pairs.

Fetches real-time mid prices (average of best bid and best ask) for the specified
trading pairs from a single exchange connector. This is the fastest way to get
current price data for multiple pairs simultaneously.

Mid price is calculated as: (best_bid + best_ask) / 2

This provides a fair market price that's commonly used for:
- Portfolio valuation
- Price displays and charts
- Strategy calculations
- Triggering price alerts

Get funding rate information for a perpetual futures trading pair.

Retrieves current funding rate data for perpetual futures contracts. Funding rates
are periodic payments exchanged between long and short position holders to keep
the perpetual price aligned with the spot price.

Understanding funding rates:
- Positive rate: Longs pay shorts (market is bullish, longs are penalized)
- Negative rate: Shorts pay longs (market is bearish, shorts are penalized)
- Rate is typically applied every 8 hours (exchange-dependent)
- Rate is expressed as a decimal (0.0001 = 0.01% = 1 basis point)

IMPORTANT: This endpoint only works with perpetual futures connectors.
The connector_name must contain "_perpetual" (e.g., "binance_perpetual").

Get a snapshot of the order book for a trading pair.

Retrieves the current state of the order book (limit order book / LOB) showing
buy orders (bids) and sell orders (asks) at various price levels. This data is
essential for understanding market depth, liquidity, and potential slippage.

Order book terminology:
- Bids: Buy orders, sorted highest to lowest (best bid first)
- Asks: Sell orders, sorted lowest to highest (best ask first)
- Spread: Difference between lowest ask and highest bid
- Depth: Number of price levels on each side

The order book snapshot represents the market state at a specific moment.
For real-time order book tracking, make periodic requests.

Calculate the price required to fill a specific base asset volume.

Analyzes the order book to determine the worst price you would pay (for buys)
or receive (for sells) when executing a market order of the specified volume.
This helps estimate slippage and price impact before placing an order.

How it works:
- For BUYS (is_buy=true): Walks up the ask side, accumulating volume
- For SELLS (is_buy=false): Walks down the bid side, accumulating volume
- Returns the price of the last level needed to fill the full volume

Use cases:
- Estimate slippage before executing a large order
- Set realistic limit prices based on available liquidity
- Compare execution costs across different venues

Calculate cumulative volume available up to a specific price level.

Analyzes the order book to determine how much base asset volume is available
between the best price and your specified price level. This helps understand
market depth and liquidity at specific price points.

How it works:
- For BUYS (is_buy=true): Sums ask volume from best ask up to the specified price
- For SELLS (is_buy=false): Sums bid volume from best bid down to the specified price
- Returns the total volume available within that price range

Use cases:
- Determine if enough liquidity exists at your target price
- Understand market depth at specific price levels
- Plan entry/exit points based on available volume

Calculate the price required to spend/receive a specific quote currency amount.

Analyzes the order book to determine the execution price when you want to
trade a specific amount of quote currency (e.g., "I want to spend exactly
10,000 USDT on BTC"). This is useful when you have a fixed budget in quote
currency rather than a target base asset quantity.

How it works:
- For BUYS (is_buy=true): Walks up asks until quote_volume USDT would be spent
- For SELLS (is_buy=false): Walks down bids until quote_volume USDT would be received
- Returns the price at which the full quote amount would be filled

Use cases:
- Execute trades with a fixed budget ("buy $10,000 worth of BTC")
- DCA strategies with fixed investment amounts
- Compare quote-based execution across venues

Calculate cumulative quote volume available up to a specific price level.

Similar to volume-for-price but returns the result in quote currency terms.
This tells you how much quote currency (e.g., USDT) worth of orders exist
between the best price and your target price level.

How it works:
- For BUYS (is_buy=true): Sums (price * volume) for asks up to specified price
- For SELLS (is_buy=false): Sums (price * volume) for bids down to specified price
- Returns total quote value available within that range

Use cases:
- Understand market depth in dollar/USDT terms
- Evaluate if sufficient quote liquidity exists for your trade size
- Compare liquidity across different markets using a common denomination

Calculate Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP) for filling a specific volume.

Computes the average price you would pay (for buys) or receive (for sells)
when executing an order of the specified volume, weighted by the amount
filled at each price level. This is one of the most important metrics for
understanding true execution cost.

VWAP Calculation:
VWAP = Sum(price_i * volume_i) / Sum(volume_i)

This differs from result_price (worst fill price) because it accounts for
the fact that most of your order may fill at better prices, with only the
tail filling at worse prices.

Use cases:
- Calculate true expected execution cost for market orders
- Benchmark algorithmic execution against market VWAP
- Compare execution quality across different venues
- Set realistic price expectations for large orders

get.description:
List all available rate oracle data sources.

Returns the list of supported exchanges and data providers that can be used
as rate oracle sources. The rate oracle fetches price data from the configured
source to convert between different quote currencies.

Use this endpoint to discover available sources before configuring the rate oracle,
or to verify that a specific exchange is supported.

schema.title: Response Get Available Sources Rate Oracle Sources Get

get.description:
Get the current rate oracle configuration.

Retrieves the current rate oracle settings from conf_client.yml, including the
configured price data source and global token settings. The global token is
used for normalizing all values to a common quote currency (e.g., USD or USDT).

Use this endpoint to check current settings before making changes, or to verify
that configuration updates were applied correctly.

put.description:
Update the rate oracle configuration.

Modifies the rate oracle source and/or global token settings. Changes are applied
immediately to the running RateOracle instance and persisted to conf_client.yml
for future sessions.

You can update either the rate_oracle_source, global_token, or both in a single
request. Only the fields provided will be updated.

post.description:
Get exchange rates for multiple trading pairs.

Fetches the current exchange rates for a list of trading pairs using the configured
rate oracle source. Rates are returned as the price of the base asset in terms of
the quote asset. Uses cached price data for fast responses.

Use this endpoint to get rates for multiple pairs in a single request, which is
more efficient than making individual requests.

get.description:
Get the exchange rate for a single trading pair.

Fetches the current exchange rate for a specific trading pair using cached price
data from the rate oracle. This is a synchronous lookup that uses previously
fetched data, making it very fast.

Use this endpoint for quick rate lookups when you only need a single pair.
For multiple pairs, use the POST /rates endpoint instead.

Get a fresh exchange rate directly from the source (bypasses cache).

Fetches the current exchange rate for a trading pair directly from the configured
rate oracle source, bypassing any cached data. This is slower than the cached
endpoint but guarantees fresh data.

Use this endpoint when you need the most up-to-date rate and can tolerate
slightly higher latency, or when the rate oracle cache hasn't been initialized yet.

Get all cached prices from the rate oracle.

Returns the complete set of prices that the rate oracle has fetched and cached
from its configured source. This includes all trading pairs available from the
source exchange, not just those you've queried.

Use this endpoint to explore available trading pairs, debug rate oracle issues,
or pre-fetch all prices for client-side caching.

post.description:
Run a historical backtesting simulation for a controller configuration.

Executes a complete backtesting simulation using historical market data to evaluate
how a trading strategy would have performed over a specified time period. The backtest
simulates trade execution, tracks positions, and calculates performance metrics.

The controller configuration can be provided either as a path to a YAML file or
as a complete configuration dictionary. Historical candle data is automatically
fetched for the required trading pairs and time period.

Use this endpoint to evaluate strategy performance before deploying to live trading,
optimize strategy parameters, or compare different configurations.

get.description:
List all available archived bot database files.

Scans the system for SQLite database files from archived Hummingbot bot instances.
These databases contain historical trading data including orders, trades, executors,
and controller configurations.

Use this endpoint to discover available archived bots before querying their data,
or to verify that a bot's data was properly archived after removal.

schema.title: Response List Databases Archived Bots Get

get.description:
Check the health status of a bot database.

Validates the database structure and checks that all expected tables are present
and accessible. This is useful for verifying database integrity before querying
trading data.

Use this endpoint to verify a database is valid before running detailed queries,
or to diagnose issues with corrupted or incomplete archives.

Get a high-level summary of an archived bot's trading activity.

Retrieves aggregate statistics from the database including total counts for
orders, trades, executors, positions, and controllers. Also identifies the
unique trading pairs and exchanges used by the bot.

Use this endpoint to get a quick overview of a bot's activity before
diving into detailed trade or order data.

Calculate comprehensive trading performance metrics for an archived bot.

Analyzes all trades in the database to compute performance metrics including
realized and unrealized PnL, fees, volume, and net position. Returns both
summary statistics and detailed per-trade performance data with rolling
calculations.

Use this endpoint to evaluate a bot's historical trading performance,
analyze profitability, or generate performance reports.

Get paginated trade fill history from an archived bot database.

Retrieves trade execution records with details including price, amount, fees,
and timestamps. Supports pagination for handling large trade histories.

Use this endpoint to analyze individual trades, export trade data, or
build detailed trade history reports.

schema.title: Limit

schema.title: Offset

Get paginated order history from an archived bot database.

Retrieves order records with details including order type, status, amounts,
and timestamps. Supports pagination and optional filtering by order status.

Use this endpoint to analyze order patterns, review order fill rates, or
investigate specific order outcomes.

schema.title: Status

parameters.description: Filter by order status: OPEN, FILLED, CANCELLED, FAILED

get.description:
Get executor records from an archived bot database.

Retrieves executor data showing the trading actions performed by V2 strategy
controllers. Executors represent individual trading operations with their
configurations, entry/exit details, and PnL results.

Use this endpoint to analyze controller performance, review executor outcomes,
or debug strategy behavior at the executor level.

Get paginated position history from an archived bot database.

Retrieves position records tracking the bot's open and closed positions over time.
Positions aggregate multiple orders and trades into logical position entries.

Use this endpoint to analyze position sizing, holding periods, or track the
bot's exposure over time.

get.description:
Get controller configuration records from an archived bot database.

Retrieves records of V2 strategy controllers that were running on the bot,
including their configurations and performance summaries. This shows what
strategies were deployed and how they were configured.

Use this endpoint to review what controllers were active, verify configuration
settings, or analyze controller-level performance.

patch.description:
Forward request to Gateway server unchanged.

Transparent proxy that forwards any request to the Gateway server. The request
body, headers, query parameters, and HTTP method are passed through unchanged.
The response from Gateway is returned unchanged to the client.

This endpoint supports all HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, PATCH) and
any path under /gateway-proxy/.

get.description:
Forward request to Gateway server unchanged.

Transparent proxy that forwards any request to the Gateway server. The request
body, headers, query parameters, and HTTP method are passed through unchanged.
The response from Gateway is returned unchanged to the client.

This endpoint supports all HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, PATCH) and
any path under /gateway-proxy/.

Forward request to Gateway server unchanged.

Transparent proxy that forwards any request to the Gateway server. The request
body, headers, query parameters, and HTTP method are passed through unchanged.
The response from Gateway is returned unchanged to the client.

This endpoint supports all HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, PATCH) and
any path under /gateway-proxy/.

Forward request to Gateway server unchanged.

Transparent proxy that forwards any request to the Gateway server. The request

This endpoint supports all HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, PATCH) and

Forward request to Gateway server unchanged.

get.description:
Gateway health check.

Checks if the Gateway server is running and responsive by calling its root endpoint.
Use this to verify Gateway connectivity before making other requests.
API root endpoint returning basic information.

AccountsDistributionFilterRequest.title: AccountsDistributionFilterRequest
AccountsDistributionFilterRequest.description:
Request model for filtering portfolio distribution by account.

Used to query how the portfolio is distributed across different accounts,
with optional filtering by connector.

Example:
    ```json
    {
        "account_names": ["main_account", "trading_account"],
        "connector_names": ["binance"]
    }
    ```

ActiveOrderFilterRequest.title: ActiveOrderFilterRequest
ActiveOrderFilterRequest.description:
Request model for filtering currently active (in-flight) orders.

Used to query orders that are currently open or pending on exchanges.
All filters are optional - omitting a filter includes all values for that field.

Example:
    ```json
    {
        "account_names": ["main"],
        "connector_names": ["binance"],
        "trading_pairs": ["BTC-USDT"],
        "limit": 50
    }
    ```

content.description: Python source code for the controller. Should be a valid Python module implementing a controller class that extends the appropriate Hummingbot V2 base class.

Controller.title: Controller
Controller.description: Request model for creating or updating a controller Python file.

ControllerType.title: ControllerType
ControllerType.description:
Types of V2 strategy controllers available in Hummingbot.

- DIRECTIONAL_TRADING: Controllers for trend-following, signal-based, or momentum strategies
- MARKET_MAKING: Controllers for market making, liquidity provision, and spread-based strategies
- GENERIC: Controllers for other strategy types like arbitrage, cross-exchange, or custom logic

connector_name.description: Name of the perpetual futures connector (must contain '_perpetual', e.g., 'binance_perpetual', 'hyperliquid_perpetual')

trading_pair.title: Trading Pair
trading_pair.description: Perpetual trading pair to get funding info for (e.g., 'BTC-USDT', 'ETH-USDT')

FundingInfoRequest.title: FundingInfoRequest
FundingInfoRequest.description:
Request model for fetching perpetual futures funding information.

Only valid for perpetual futures connectors (connector names containing '_perpetual').
Use this to get current funding rates, next funding time, and reference prices.

trading_pair.title: Trading Pair
trading_pair.description: Perpetual trading pair

funding_rate.title: Funding Rate
funding_rate.description: Current funding rate as a decimal (e.g., 0.0001 = 0.01%). Positive means longs pay shorts.

next_funding_time.title: Next Funding Time
next_funding_time.description: Unix timestamp (in seconds) of the next funding payment. Funding is typically every 8 hours.

mark_price.title: Mark Price
mark_price.description: Current mark price used for liquidation calculations and funding rate computation

index_price.title: Index Price
index_price.description: Current index price (aggregate price from multiple spot exchanges) used as reference

FundingInfoResponse.title: FundingInfoResponse
FundingInfoResponse.description:
Response containing perpetual futures funding information.

Funding rates are periodic payments between long and short position holders.
A positive rate means longs pay shorts; a negative rate means shorts pay longs.

limit.title: Limit
limit.description: Maximum number of items to return per page. Range: 1-1000. Default: 100.

start_time.title: Start Time
start_time.description: Start of time range as Unix timestamp in milliseconds (inclusive). Example: 1704067200000 for 2024-01-01 00:00:00 UTC. If omitted, no lower bound.

end_time.title: End Time
end_time.description: End of time range as Unix timestamp in milliseconds (inclusive). Example: 1704153600000 for 2024-01-02 00:00:00 UTC. If omitted, no upper bound.

account_names.title: Account Names
account_names.description: Filter by account names. If omitted, queries all accounts.

connector_names.title: Connector Names
connector_names.description: Filter by perpetual connector names. If omitted, queries all perpetual connectors. Spot connectors are always excluded.

trading_pair.title: Trading Pair
trading_pair.description: Filter by a single trading pair (e.g., 'BTC-USDT'). If omitted, queries all pairs.

FundingPaymentFilterRequest.title: FundingPaymentFilterRequest
FundingPaymentFilterRequest.description:
Request model for filtering funding payment history from perpetual connectors.

Used to query historical funding payments (periodic payments between longs and shorts
to keep perpetual prices aligned with spot). Supports time-range filtering.

Example:
    ```json
    {
        "account_names": ["main"],
        "connector_names": ["binance_perpetual"],
        "trading_pair": "BTC-USDT",
        "start_time": 1704067200000,
        "end_time": 1704153600000,
        "limit": 100
    }
    ```

chain.title: Chain
chain.description: Blockchain chain name. Supported chains: 'solana' (for Jupiter, Raydium, Meteora), 'ethereum' (for Uniswap), and other EVM chains configured in Gateway.

private_key.title: Private Key
private_key.description: The wallet's private key. Format varies by chain: Solana: Base58-encoded (88 chars). Ethereum/EVM: Hex-encoded (64 chars, with or without 0x prefix).

network.title: Network
network.description: Network to use for this wallet. If not specified, uses the chain's default network. Examples: 'mainnet-beta' for Solana mainnet, 'mainnet' for Ethereum mainnet.

GatewayWalletCredential.title: GatewayWalletCredential
GatewayWalletCredential.description:
Credentials for importing a blockchain wallet into Gateway.

Used to add an existing wallet to Gateway for DEX trading. Gateway encrypts
and stores the private key securely.

Example:
    {
        "chain": "solana",
        "private_key": "4wBqpZM9xrMqRQsC8gxEh..."
    }

global_token_name.title: Global Token Name
global_token_name.description: The token to use as global quote (e.g., USDT, USD, BTC)

global_token_symbol.title: Global Token Symbol
global_token_symbol.description: Symbol to display for the global token

GlobalTokenConfig.title: GlobalTokenConfig
GlobalTokenConfig.description: Global token configuration for displaying values.

trading_pair.title: Trading Pair
trading_pair.description: Trading pair to set leverage for, in BASE-QUOTE format (e.g., 'BTC-USDT', 'ETH-USDC'). Must be a valid perpetual trading pair on the connector.

leverage.title: Leverage
leverage.description: Leverage multiplier value. Valid range depends on the exchange and trading pair. Common ranges: 1-125 for Binance, 1-100 for OKX. Higher leverage = higher risk.

LeverageRequest.title: LeverageRequest
LeverageRequest.description:
Request model for setting leverage on perpetual/futures connectors.

Leverage determines the multiplier applied to your margin when opening positions.
Higher leverage increases both potential profits and losses.

Example:
    {
        "trading_pair": "BTC-USDT",
        "leverage": 10
    }

Represents the total amount available at a specific price point.

trading_pair.description: Trading pair that was analyzed

is_buy.description: True if this was a buy-side query, False for sell-side

query_volume.description: The base asset volume that was queried (if applicable)

query_price.title: Query Price
query_price.description: The price level that was queried (if applicable)

result_price.title: Result Price
result_price.description: Resulting price from the query. For price-for-volume queries, this is the worst price needed to fill the order.

result_volume.title: Result Volume
result_volume.description: Resulting base asset volume from the query. For volume-for-price queries, this is the total available liquidity.

result_quote_volume.title: Result Quote Volume
result_quote_volume.description: Resulting quote currency volume. Total value in quote currency for the calculated order.

average_price.title: Average Price
average_price.description: Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP). The average price across all price levels consumed.

timestamp.title: Timestamp
timestamp.description: Unix timestamp (in seconds) when the query was executed

OrderBookQueryResult.title: OrderBookQueryResult
OrderBookQueryResult.description:
Response containing results from order book analysis queries.

Different fields are populated depending on the query type:
- price-for-volume: result_price shows the worst fill price
- volume-for-price: result_volume shows available liquidity
- vwap: average_price shows the volume-weighted average price

Note: If insufficient liquidity exists, result fields may be None.

connector_name.title: Connector Name
connector_name.description: Name of the exchange connector to fetch order book from

trading_pair.title: Trading Pair
trading_pair.description: Trading pair to get order book for in hyphen-separated format

depth.title: Depth
depth.description: Number of price levels to return on each side (bids and asks). Higher values provide more market depth but larger responses.

OrderBookRequest.title: OrderBookRequest
OrderBookRequest.description:
Request model for fetching an order book snapshot.

Order books show the current buy (bid) and sell (ask) orders at various price levels.
Use depth to limit how many price levels are returned.

trading_pair.title: Trading Pair
trading_pair.description: Trading pair for this order book

bids.title: Bids
bids.description: List of bid (buy) orders sorted from highest to lowest price. First entry is the best bid.

asks.title: Asks
asks.description: List of ask (sell) orders sorted from lowest to highest price. First entry is the best ask.

timestamp.title: Timestamp
timestamp.description: Unix timestamp (in seconds) when this snapshot was taken

OrderBookResponse.title: OrderBookResponse
OrderBookResponse.description:
Response containing an order book snapshot.

Bids are sorted from highest to lowest price (best bids first).
Asks are sorted from lowest to highest price (best asks first).
The spread is the difference between the lowest ask and highest bid.

connector_names.description: Filter by connector names (e.g., ['binance', 'kucoin']). If omitted, queries all connectors.

OrderFilterRequest.title: OrderFilterRequest
OrderFilterRequest.description:
Request model for searching historical orders with multiple filter criteria.

Supports filtering by account, connector, trading pair, status, and time range.
All filters are optional - omitting a filter includes all values for that field.

Example:
    ```json
    {
        "account_names": ["main", "trading"],
        "connector_names": ["binance"],
        "trading_pairs": ["BTC-USDT", "ETH-USDT"],
        "status": "FILLED",
        "start_time": 1704067200000,
        "end_time": 1704153600000,
        "limit": 100
    }
    ```

data.description: Array of result items. Structure depends on the specific endpoint.

pagination.description: Pagination metadata containing: `limit` (items per page), `has_more` (boolean, true if more results exist), `next_cursor` (string, pass to cursor param for next page, null if no more pages), `total_count` (total items matching the query across all pages).

        "account_names": ["main_account", "trading_account"],

    }

connector_names.title: Connector Names
connector_names.description: Filter to specific connectors. If null/empty, returns history for all connectors.

interval.title: Interval
interval.description: Data sampling interval. Larger intervals reduce data volume. Valid values: '5m' (raw), '15m', '30m', '1h', '4h', '12h', '1d'

PortfolioHistoryFilterRequest.title: PortfolioHistoryFilterRequest
PortfolioHistoryFilterRequest.description:
Request model for querying historical portfolio snapshots.

Retrieves historical portfolio state data with configurable time intervals
for data sampling. Larger intervals reduce response size and improve performance.
Portfolio snapshots are collected every 5 minutes.

Example:
    ```json
    {
        "account_names": ["main_account"],
        "connector_names": ["binance"],
        "start_time": 1704067200000,
        "end_time": 1704153600000,
        "interval": "1h",
        "limit": 100,
        "cursor": null
    }
    ```

account_names.title: Account Names
account_names.description: Filter to specific accounts. If null/empty, returns all accounts.

connector_names.title: Connector Names
connector_names.description: Filter to specific connectors/exchanges. If null/empty, returns all connectors.

skip_gateway.title: Skip Gateway
skip_gateway.description: If true, skip Gateway (DEX) wallet balance updates. Significantly faster for CEX-only queries.

refresh.title: Refresh
refresh.description: If true, fetch fresh balances from exchanges (slower but accurate). If false, return cached state (faster).

PortfolioStateFilterRequest.title: PortfolioStateFilterRequest
PortfolioStateFilterRequest.description:
Request model for filtering and controlling portfolio state retrieval.

Controls which accounts and connectors to include in the portfolio state,
and whether to return cached data or fetch fresh balances from exchanges.

Example:
    ```json
    {
        "account_names": ["main_account"],
        "connector_names": ["binance", "bybit"],
        "skip_gateway": false,
        "refresh": true
    }
    ```

limit.title: Limit
limit.description: Maximum number of items to return per page. Range: 1-1000. Default: 100.
